1 your aim and assumption determine your methodology. If you wanna look at the correlations between usage of electronic device/online behaviour patterns and personality/behavioural problems, how do you prove that the former is the necessary and sufficient condition for the latter? Effects of other factors? Siblings interactions? Parent disciplinary style? Socio-economic factors? Other pre-existing conditions of the kids themselves? Goodness of fit? Other risk factors? How to control ? And how to prove direction of causality?

2 this self-administered questionnaire is distributed online. Many are using smart phones to answer. How do you make it a user-friendly experience?

3 since this is self-administered not telephone not face-to-face interview, your respondents are not able to clarify with you simultaneously about the questions. Ambiguity should be minimised. Especially about the self-rating battery.

4 your target sample? You assume every respondent only have one kid? Beware of experimenter bias creeping into your design

5 translation problems

å¥½å¤šè¬ä½ å’æ¯”å¿ƒæ©Ÿè¦†ï¼ŒåŒå’æ¯”å¿ƒæ©Ÿç‡æˆ‘ä»½å•å·ï¼Œå’æˆ‘éƒ½æ¯”å¿ƒæ©Ÿè¦†ä½ å•¦ å“ˆå“ˆ

1. This is true. Yet, there are a lot of contributing factors related to mental health issues. However, my study is not trying to find a CAUSAL relationship. The core of a correlation analysis is only determining the relationship between the constructs that I proposed. Hence, there are many correlation analyses between many constructs (vulnerability, sibling interaction, etc) and mental health. But my study only focuses on mental health.

This is an explorative study. The key is, there might not be any correlations between internet use and mental health problems. My study does not guarantee a significant correlation between the two. There is a good chance that they have no correlations at all. If so, it is still a good result because this means that the severity of problematic internet use is not affecting our mental health, so people do not have to worry about ä¸Šç¶²å¤ªå¤šæœƒå½±éŸ¿å¿ƒç†å¥åº·. Of course, my hypothesis suggests the other way. Therefore, I am not proving my theory but to test if my hypothesis is true. I will accept either way.

For example, I can do a correlation study between é¤Šè²“ and mental health. The result could be no relationship at all. But we do not know if it is true until we do the study. So we need to conduct this study. Since there are limited studies on the level of internet use and mental health in HK, my study will be investigating if there are any relationships. If so, how strong.

2. True, it is a problem. The SDQ and Media Activity Form are developed by multiple psychologists to specialise in measuring them with good reliability and validity. However, they are supposed to be filled in paper form. They are very short questionnaires on paper, but might be troublesome to do online. However, I must include all questions and retain their forms because any changes will affect the reliability.

However, based on the population response, the average duration to fill in is ~15 mins, which is consistent with my estimated time stated on the first page. I hope people to reserve time yo fill in this. But I know that it’s hard.

replies.msg:
3. This is a solely quantitative study. No qualitative data will be analysed. However, there are “Comment” questions following every questions for them to express anything they want to, including ambiguity and additional information. Although these will not be analysed, the comments are taken into account for interpretation of the result.

4. The parent can do the questionnaire once for each kid. i.e. I can do it for 4 times if I have 4 kids.

5. As stated in (2), the questionnaires are developed by psychologists and the translations are tested for reliability and validity. While I adopt the translated version, I should not change too many wordings as it might affect the reliability and validity. However, I have already made some minor changes including typos.
